name: Get Organized for Research
summary: Taking the time to get well-organized now will save you time later, and it will help you research your ancestor lines efficiently. Here is a good overview of getting organized with your genealogy materials.

choices.name: Organize your materials.

hidden.content:
• Being organized while working on genealogy will help prevent duplicate research and make it clear where all information came from.
  • A physical binder with dividers for subcategories can help in organizing research and making research aids easily accessible.
  • Having a filing system (digital or physical) will help organize data and findings. Organizing by locality, then record type, then family line is one way many people prefer to arrange their documents.

• Items you will need
  • Let's get our chart
  • Color system
  • Numbering our sections
  • Pages for each binder
  • What is in each section?
  • Keep track of your documents

• Start with one document
  • Cross-references
  • Two levels of complexity
  • Choose a program
  • Orgainzation based on sources
  • Scan all documents and photos
  • Attach scanned images to each person in document
  • As you add documents ...
  • Step-by-step summary

• * Good: Write down key learnings from the article in this Choice.
  • * Proficient: Same as above. Then create a research binder and organize your papers and materials in it.

content.text:
1. Here are some tips to get started with organizing your genealogy.

    ☆ FS: Organize Your Genealogy - 2021
    ☆ FL—Family History & Getting Things Done: Part 3, Organization - 2019


    2. Research Binders
  2. Get a research binder and add page dividers in it, by geographic place of research or family surname.
  3. Determine your own sub-categories within the dividers, such as maps, how-to's, information contacts and websites, where to order records, printed forms, brief blog posts and articles, etc.
  4. Watch this video for tips on creating a research binder.

    ☆ Family History Organization—13:17 - 2017

    • Color system
    • Numbering our sections
    • Pages for each binder
    • What is in each section?
    • Keep track of your documents




  5. Learn how a research notebook helps with organizing genealogy.

    ☆ How a Research Notebook Can Keep You Organized - 2011

Research Binders
Research Organization
  1. Use these tips to help you stay organized with your research.

    ☆ FS—Organizing Your Files
    ☆ BYU—Organizing Genealogy Files—15:25 - 2015

    • Cross-references

    • Orgainzation based on sources

    • Attach scanned images to each person in document

  2. Here are additional ideas for organizing your research and your findings.

  4. Explore the Organize Your Family History blog site for additional ideas and interviews about staying organized with your genealogy.
  5. Learn about using Google Drive to organize your genealogy.

    ☆ RT—Organize Your Research with Google Drive - 2019

choices.name: Create and use to-do lists to keep on track with your research.

hidden.content:
• To-do lists with small but focused tasks will help you achieve research goals.
  • Electronic or physical to-do lists are both viable ways to track your progress.

• Write as you go
  • Create a family timeline
  • Collect mementos and tell their story
  • Record audio/video
• * Proficient: Decide on a to-do list format and populate it with the family history tasks you need to accomplish in the coming week.

content.text:
This helps you remember where to begin and how to stay on target with your goals.

  1. Decide on small, focused tasks for your to-do list. Make sure your tasks support the goals you are working on.
  2. Use an electronic to-do list (Outlook, iPhone, word processing document, or spreadsheet) or a paper-based list.
  3. To get started with the FamilySearch To-Do List, a) On the www.familysearch.org page, find To-Do List (right side); b) In the "Add an Item" box, type the task you want to keep track of; and c) Click Add.
  4. To mark a FamilySearch To-Do List item as completed, click its check box. To hide or show the item, click Hide or Show. To delete an item, move the pointer to the right-hand edge of the item and click the red "X".
  5. For tips on using the Ancestry To-Do List, see Choice C in Ancestry, Project 4: Goal 7.

resources.description: This article explains how to turn genealogy clues into "to do's".

links.text: RT—Turning Genealogy Clues into Genealogy To Do's - 2019

resources.description: Learn how checklists can aid in your research tasks.

links.text: How Genealogy Checklists Will Improve Your Research

resources.description: Study these videos for tips on writing down research learnings and keeping effective to-do lists.

choices.name: Use notes, logs, and software to stay organized as you research.

hidden.content:
• Research logs are essential in tracking what was searched, where was looked, and what was found.
  • Providing as much information as possible when citing a document is important to help find it again.
  • Taking notes while you research will help you quickly recall relevant information. Make sure to record sources, use a person’s full name, and carefully pay attention to dates.
  • Store the records you're working with in several places, such as FamilySearch's Source Box.

• What is a research log?
  • Why use a research log?
  • Research logs contain ...
  • Example
  • Make up your own logs
  • Where to find blank logs
  • Keep track of your crazy clicking
  • Cut and paste URLs
  • To learn more ...
• * Proficient: Write down the key learnings from the Choice. Then set up a research log and begin using it to track your research.

content.text:
Notes and Logs
  1. Learn about taking effective notes as you do research.

    ☆ GC—Taking Notes in Genealogy
    ☆ GTV—Research Notes—7:28 - 2018



  2. Use research logs to track your progress.

    ☆ BYU—Research Logs—6:50 - 2014  
    • What is a research log?
    • Why use a research log?
    • Research logs contain ...
    • Example
    • Make up your own logs
    • Where to find blank logs
    • Keep track of your crazy clicking
    • Cut and paste URLs
    • To learn more ...



    ☆ FS—Research Logs

  3. Learn how to effectively combine research logs with your research plan.

    ☆ GTV: Research Logs, Episode 8—7:36 - 2018



  4. Here are some tips on writing genealogical reports for your research.

    ☆ Writing Genealogical Reports

  5. Store lists of records you are working on in the FamilySearch Source Box or the Ancestry Shoebox. You can also use a spreadsheet, such as this downloadable Document Tracker from Fortify Your Family Tree.
Software
  1. Learn how to use spreadsheets to organize your genealogy research.

    ☆ RT—Using Spreadsheets to Track and Organize Your Research - 2019

  2. Learn how to create research logs with Airtable, a hybrid spreadsheet/database.

    ☆ FL—Airtable Research Logs - 2020

  3. Learn how to use Evernote for organizing genealogy.

    ☆ FHD—Master Genealogy Organization in an Hour with One Online Program
    ☆ Evernote for Genealogy: What It Is, & Why You Would Use It—5:21 - 2015



  4. Learn more about Evernote techniques for genealogy.

    ☆ FL—Using Evernote for Genealogy Research - 2018

  5. If you use Microsoft Office, take advantage of OneNote for organizing your genealogy.

    ☆ FS—Organizing Your Genealogy Using Microsoft OneNote
    ☆ Get Organized with OneNote

  6. Learn how to use Google Chrome shortcuts to accelerate your research.

    ☆ RT—How to Create Google Chrome Shortcuts for Faster Genealogy Research—4:58 - 2021

choices.name: Keep track of your correspondence with others and write effective request messages.

hidden.content:
• Carefully tracking correspondence research with each individual will ensure that research isn’t duplicated.
  • Ongoing communication between everyone involved in the research process is key.

• * Good: Identify a family member or organization you would like to write to for genealogy information. Using the tips in this Choice to guide you, write to that person about your needs or questions.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, corresponding with at least three people.

content.text:
1. Read this article for tips on tracking your correspondence with others. See also the Correspondence Record form in Choice E.

    ☆ Genealogy Correspondence Sheets: How Do I Get Started? - 2016

  2. Here are tips for writing to family members and organizations.

    ☆ Correspondence to Family Members
    ☆ GC—Tips for Writing to Institutions

  3. You can use these form letters and tips when writing to people internationally.

    ☆ GC—Form Letters for Requesting Information

  4. Make use of email or text-message folders for electronic correspondence.

choices.name: Use pre-printed charts to help you organize your research efforts.

hidden.content:
• Track the names of possible ancestors.
  • Track the resources you have explored.
  • Summarize the data you researched.
  • Track your correspondence with others.
  • Track sources for individuals and families.

• * Good: Use 2 of the pre-printed forms in this Choice to track at least one ancestor.
  • * Proficient: Use at least 5 of the pre-printed forms in this Choice to track more than one ancestor.

content.text:
1. Use free genealogy research forms from Family Search and other resources. Here are some useful sources:
    • FamilySearch
    • National Archives and Record Administration
    • Archives.com
    • Ancestry.com
    • Genealogy Bank to record information on members of a family you are researching.
    • The Baileys
    • FamilyTree Magazine
    • Price Genealogy
    • Family Education
    • Cyndi's List
  2. Learn how to stay organized with family tree charts and software.

    ☆ GTV—Stay Organized with Family Tree Charts and Software—6:10 - 2018

name: Learn genealogy basics
section_name: Learn genealogy basics and identify a line to research.Vault

choices.name: Learn basic concepts in genealogy research.

hidden.content:
• Work backwards in time.
  • Get help with documents and details from family and relatives.
  • Learn what research has already been done in your family, so you can verify it.

• Research methodology
  • Learning about records
  • Research begins ...
  • Main objective
  • Basic concepts
  • Steps of research
  • Move from known to unknown
  • Begin with a known place
  • Examine entries in online trees
  • Verify places and dates

• * Good: Write down at least two tips from the articles or video that you plan to use in making your research effective.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, with at least four tips.

content.text:
1. Understand the basic research process:
    1) Gather known information; 2) Choose a research goal; 3) Find new information; 4) Evaluate new information; 5) Share new information.

    ☆ FS—Research Process - Introduction—5:04 - 2018

  2. Research Principles: Study these tips for starting your genealogy research.

    ☆ Top Ten Tips for Starting Your Family History
    ☆ FMP—5 Steps to Starting Your Family History - 2019

  3. Watch these videos for an overview of doing genealogy research.

    ☆ FS—Getting Started in Genealogy—10:09
    ☆ BYU—Fundamentals of Research—54:08

    ☆ Getting Started on Your Family History

  5. Here are some important principles that every researcher should know.

    ☆ FHD—The 10 Hard Truths Every Family Historian Must Learn

resources.description: Terms and Abbreviations: Learn important genealogical terms for your research. You can return to these lists over time and increase your knowledge of terms for your research.
Learn about abbreviations used in documents and genealogy research.

links.text: FHD—What Does That Mean? 300+ Family History Abbreviations Explained

resources.description: Charts and Relationships: Get familiar with pedigree charts and family group sheets and how they are used. For free charts and forms, see Goal 12 in Project 1: Family Tree.
Learn about basic family relationships with this chart from the Irish Family History Centre.

links.text: Family Tree Explained – Family Relationship Chart

choices.name: Identify a line to begin researching.

hidden.content:
• Choose a line that's interesting to you but not a brick wall.
  • Choose a line that is likely to have available records.
  • For easier research, choose a line with less common names and in your home country.

• * Good: Identify an ancestor who would be a good candidate for opening a line of research.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, for 3 ancestors.

content.text:
Choosing one line at a time to pursue is a more efficient way to do research. Try to gather as much information about a given family unit as possible, before tracing back additional generations: work backwards in time.

  1. If possible, look for someone who was born after 1700, with a recorded spouse.
  2. View or print a family group sheet for the person. Make note of missing names, dates and locations in the records of recent ancestors.
  3. See the Puzzilla.org Goal in FamilySearch Project 3 for instructions on displaying an ancestor view. Nodes without extensions are the end-of-line ancestors. To highlight these nodes so they stand out more easily, click Targets in the left pane.

resources.description: Here are some tips for choosing a line to research.

links.text: FS Wiki—Deciding Which Ancestors to Trace

resources.description: Read this article for tips on finding missing parents in your line.

links.text: Five Uncommon Places to Find Your Ancestors' Missing Parents

resources.description: Plan to search for all your ancestors, not just the direct male or female lines.
Use the Ancestor Source Finder to locate possible source records for ancestors in your tree.

links.text: LDS—How to Use the Ancestor Source Finder—1:50 - 2023

choices.name: Form questions for each selected ancestor that will help drive your research.

hidden.content:
• Note Step 1.
  • Ask the questions of who (people), when (dates), where (locations), and what (events and record types).
  • Take larger questions and break them down into smaller, specific ones.

• Purpose of research questions
  • Bad questions
  • Event-based questions
  • Biographical questions
  • Researching your question
  • Start with yourself
  • Add research evidence
  • Gather facts
  • Improve the research question

• * Good: Write down two or more research questions for one of your ancestors.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, for three ancestors.

content.text:
1. Ask the questions you're most interested in: Why did an ancestor move? Are there missing children in a gap on a family group record? Watch these videos for ideas.

    ☆ FHF—How to Ask Productive Research Questions—10:04 - 2019  
    • Purpose of research questions
    • Bad questions
    • Event-based questions
    • Biographical questions
    • Researching your question
    • Start with yourself
    • Add research evidence
    • Gather facts
    • Improve the research question




  2. For a review of questions for ancestor research, watch this video.

    ☆ AC—Asking Genealogy Questions and Getting Answers—17:20 - 2016



  3. Learn how questions fit into a good research plan.

    ☆ FL—Research Like a Pro, Part 1: What's Your Question? - 2017

  4. Here are some questions to ask yourself before starting your research.

    ☆ AF—9 Questions to Ask Yourself Before You Start Researching Your Family Tree - 2020

name: Forming a Strategy
section_name: Form solid strategies to research your selected lines. Vault
summary:
A good research strategy will help you get more research done in less time. It will also help you know when to spend more time on a line and when to move on to the next one.

Note : If you have not done so already, you may want to review the Genealogical Proof Standard in Project 1 (scroll down) to learn its basic principles.

choices.name: Learn how to create and use research strategies.

hidden.content:
• Genealogy standards include "HOLA": Honesty with the data, Openness to other possibilities, Logical conclusions, Attribution to proper sources.
  • "SPDLA" = Short list of objectives; Process & evaluate the information you find; Don't fixate on finding a certain detail; Don't limit the record types you search; Attach notes to individuals in your tree (FamilySearch, Ancestry, etc.).

• * Good: Write down three strategies from this Choice and decide how you can apply them in your research for one or more ancestors.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, with 5 strategies.

content.text:
1. Learn to focus your research efforts for better results.

    ☆ LDS—Focusing Your Research

  2. Use the WANDER approach to research, as explained by Amy Johnson Crow.

    ☆ AJC—The Genealogy Research Process: The WANDER Method - 2020

  3. Use time-saving tips from these articles to make your research more efficient.

    ☆ GC—Time-Saving Tips for Genealogists
    ☆ GC—What You Can Do in Two Days

  4. Learn about the art of estimating ("guessing") in your preliminary research.

    ☆ FS—How to Guess Where to Start

  5. Understand where to look for the records you need.

    ☆ LDS—Keys to Finding Relevant Genealogical Resources
    ☆ LDS—Searching through Layers of Sources

  6. Study the strategies for research in these articles.

    ☆ FS Wiki—A Guide to Research
    ☆ AC—5 Tips to Jumpstart Your Research—7 pgs. - 2016

  7. Here's a 14-day plan for developing a research strategy, from Family Locket.

    ☆ FL—How To Research in 30 Minutes a Day: Research Like a Pro 14-Day Mini Challenge - 2022

  8. Explore the FamilySearch Community to read or post questions about research.

choices.name: Devise a research plan to use.

hidden.content:
• List what you know (including background info), then what you want to know, then make some best guesses.
  • Start with broad goals and narrow them down to focused goals ("who are my grandparents' parents?").
  • Trace one or two generations at a time; don't go back too far, too fast.

• * Good: Create a research plan for one of your ancestors.
  • * Proficient: Create a research plan for two of your ancestors.

content.text:
1. Learn how to develop a solid research plan.

    ☆ LT—5 Steps to Developing a Genealogy Research Plan
    ☆ GE: How to Structure Your Research - 2022

  2. Create broad goals and refine them into specific goals, as shown in this video.

    ☆ AC—Crafting a Research Plan—23:49 - 2012



  3. Here is a sample research plan template to use.

    ☆ Cyndi's Intermediate Research Plan Template

  4. Here are additional tips on building a research plan.

    ☆ FS—Building a Research Plan—6:03 - 2018
    ☆ FS—A Research Plan in Action—8:09 - 2018

  5. Develop a research plan in 6 steps.

    ☆ PR—How To Develop a Genealogy Research Plan in 6 Easy Steps

choices.name: Take advantage of previous research.

hidden.content:
• Learn what other research has been done by asking relatives, checking various databases, or locating family histories and genealogies.
  • Copy and analyze what was previously found.
  • Not all previous research is accurate. Locations, dates, and even names can be mistakenly recorded. Ask questions as you analyze previous research.

• Two primary types of family trees
  • Community family trees
  • Personal family trees
  • Search for an ancestor on FamilySearch
  • Summary
• * Proficient: Write down 5 key learnings from the resources in this Choice.

content.text:
The strategies in this Choice will help you when you search genealogy collections in Goal 4.

  1. Try the strategies in this FamilySearch Wiki document. Note : This document is titled as a United States article, but it applies well to research in any country.

    ☆ FS—United States Previous Research

  2. Learn how to find your ancestors in various family trees.  
    • Two primary types of family trees
    • Community family trees
    • Personal family trees
    • Search for an ancestor on FamilySearch
    • Summary


  3. Learn more about using previous research in these articles.

    ☆ GC—Previous Research in Families
    ☆ GC—Finding and Using Published Genealogies

  4. Learn about using genealogical documents and manuscripts in your research.

    ☆ FE—How to Find and Use Genealogical Documents
    ☆ AA—Using Manuscripts in Your Research—52:00 - 2015

  5. Learn to examine inherited pedigrees carefully for possible problems.

    ☆ LDS—Examine Inherited Pedigrees Carefully

  6. Here are some steps to take when you receive family history research documents from others.

    ☆ FHD—The Simple Steps to Take When You Inherit Family History Research

  7. Learn how to use and evaluate published or inherited genealogies.

    ☆ AA—Using and Evaluating Published Genealogies—60:31 - 2019



    ☆ AA—How to Progress from Inherited Research—63:00 - 2022

choices.name: Use the family memories you have collected as sources for research.

content.text:
1. Gather and summarize notes from interviews for clues on family research.
  2. Examine photos—either those in your possession or those that have been uploaded to your family history site for research clues.
  3. Examine documents such as letters, wills, diaries, etc.—either those in your possession or those that have been uploaded—for research clues. See Goal 7 in Project 2: Memories for details.
Ancestor Diaries
  1. Learn about the history of ancestor diaries.

    ☆ AF—The History of Diaries: Did Your Ancestor Keep One? - 2016

  2. Get tips on where to search for ancestor writings.

    ☆ Genealogy: Where to search for your ancestors' writings - 2013

choices.name: Study surnames and naming patterns to get clues for your research.

hidden.content:
• Surname research can help find bibliographies, pedigrees, or published family histories.
  • Surnames began to be used in Europe around 1000 AD and came from locations, occupations, or descriptions.
  • Some cultures use the same given names over and over when naming children. Sometimes surnames are used as a child's middle name.
  • Nicknames are very common and must be considered when researching an individual.
  • U.S. immigrants were sometimes recorded with Americanized forms of their names.
  • The Geneanet and Linkpendium websites can be valuable tools for surname research.

• Get started
  • Which surnames to search
  • Get a free website
  • Preserve your work
  • Benefits of a one-name study

• * Good: Write down 3 key learnings from this Choice; then explore surname research for an ancestral line.
  • * Proficient: Write down 5 key learnings from this Choice; then explore surname research for two ancestral lines.

content.text:
1. Read these articles for tips on working with names and naming patterns.

    ☆ GC—Importance of Names and Naming Patterns
    ☆ Finding the Hidden Clues in First Names: A Starter Guide

  2. Learn about tracing surnames in this article.

    ☆ TH—Last Name Meanings and Origins

  3. Read this document to learn more about surname origins. There are many sub-articles, some dealing with international names.

    ☆ TH—Surname Meanings and Origins - 2018

  4. Learn about surname research in this article from the Society of Genealogists.

    ☆ Surname Searching at the SOG

  5. Learn about the Geneanet site in this video. You can Search Geneanet.org to find your surnames of interest.

    ☆ Geneanet Tutorial—3:04 - 2016



  6. Investigate single names at the Guild of One-Name Studies site. Watch this video for more information.

    ☆ FHF—Should You Do a One-Name Genealogy Study?—14:30 - 2019  
    • Get started
    • Which surnames to search
    • Get a free website
    • Preserve your work
    • Benefits of a one-name study




  7. Explore surname research in the right column of the Linkpendium site.

name: Searching Ancestry Records
section_name: Do Ancestry searches to find ancestor information.
summary: This Goal helps you use the options available in the Ancestry Search screen for finding ancestor records.

choices.name: Do basic searches with the Search menu.

hidden.content:
• * Good: Do basic searches for two or more ancestors in your tree.
  • * Proficient: Do basic searches for five or more ancestors in your tree.

content.text:
1. In the top menu, click Search and select All Collections.


  2. Type inside the first and middle name box. A name suggestion list from your tree is displayed; you can choose a name from the list to populate search fields automatically, or continue to fill out the additional search fields.
  3. To calculate the birth year,
    a) click the calculator icon (next to the birth year field);
    b) type an age and year in the person's life; and
    c) Click OK.
  4. If desired, continue to supply information for events, family members, keywords, etc. as described in Choice B. You can also use the Collection Focus area to specify types of records and their locations.
  5. Click Search.
  6. Previous searches are listed in the "Your recent searches" section. You can click a name to do the search again, or click "View All" to see additional searches, if any.

resources.description: For more details about using basic searches, watch this video.

links.text: AC—How to Search for Records from Your Tree—0:35

resources.description: Try the search strategies in this article when working with records in Ancestry.
Read these articles to learn about searching Ancestry records and member trees.
Watch these videos for in-depth strategies for searching Ancestry records.

links.text: AAC—What Do You Want to Know?—5:24
AAC—Family and Local Histories and the Secrets of Text-Based Searches—11:21

resources.description: This article explains strategies for using the Keyword option when searching through newspapers and city directories.

links.text: Making Use of the Keyword Search Box in Ancestry.com Search to Find a Specific Village - 2015

choices.name: Use additional search options.

hidden.content:
• * Good: Do basic searches for two or more ancestors in your tree, using at least three extra options for each search.
  • * Proficient: Do basic searches for five or more ancestors in your tree, using at least three extra options for each search.

content.text:
1. (Fill in the basic search fields as noted in Choice A above.)
  2. Click "Show more options" (which becomes "Show fewer options").
  3. To require exact matches for the search terms you add, check the "Match all terms exactly" box.
  4. To add an event to the search,
    a) Click any of the event links (click More to see additional links to use); and
    b) Type the year and location for the event (if you need to remove an event from the search, click the X at the right).
  5. To add a family member to the search,
    a) Click any of the family member links (Father, Mother, Sibling, Spouse, Child); and
    b) Type the first, middle, and last names for the family member (if you need to remove an event from the search, click the X at the right).
  6. To select one or more keywords for the search, type them in the Keyword field. You can check the "Exact" box to require an exact match for the keyword text.
  7. If desired, specify the gender in the Gender drop-down list.
  8. To specify the race or nationality, type it in the Race/Nationality field. You can check the "Exact" box to require an exact match for the text.
  9. To limit the search to a certain collection, click Collection Focus and select the collection from the list.
  10. You can exclude Historical Records, Family Trees, Stories & Publications, or Photos & Maps from the search by clearing their checkboxes.
  11. Click Search.

choices.name: Search records by location.

hidden.content: • * Proficient: Do "Explore by location" searches for five or more ancestors in your tree.

content.text:
In the "Explore by Location" area you can search for records based on geography.
Note : In The Family History Guide, you can also do Ancestry searches by location in Countries and Ethnic pages, using the QUIKLinks.

  1. To explore collections, click a tab for Africa, Asia, Europe, North America, Oceania, and South America. After clicking an area tab, you can select an individual country page from the list in that area, or .
  2. To explore records for a U.S. state, click the a state on the map or a state name link. On each state page, there are tabs for Collections, History, and Resources.
  3. You can also explore records by using the map:
    a) Click the plus or minus icons to zoom the map; and
    b) Hover over a map pin to see what collections are included, and click the pin to go to the country or state page.

choices.name: Explore the Ancestry WebSearch Collection.

content.text:
Ancestry WebSearch is a collection of links to free records that reside on other sites.

  1. Get an introduction to Ancestry WebSearch in this article.

    ☆ Ancestry WebSearch

  2. Explore the Ancestry WebSearch record collection.

choices.name: Do record searches from an ancestor profile.

content.text:
1. Open an ancestor profile in your tree and click the Search button. Ancestry then searches its record collections and member trees for information that may match with the selected ancestor.
  2. The "Found in Ancestry trees" section (right side) shows a sample summary of ancestor information from an Ancestry member tree. You can click the link to go to the tree, or click "Browse more like this" to see info for this ancestor in other Ancestry trees.
  3. The Records section (right side) has links to record collections, photos, and scanned documents that mention the ancestor. Summary information is listed to the right. To show additional information for a record, hover over the record link and click View Image or View Record. If "In your hints" appears, you can click that link to see hint information for the ancestor.
    • To browse the search results by collection, click Browse by collection (upper right)..
    • To see additional search results, scroll to the bottom of the page and click the right-arrow or select a page number. You can also set the number of results per page.
    • To use keyboard shortcuts for search results, type any of the charaters indicated at the bottom of the screen.
  4. The "Your search" section (left side) shows the search fields that were used. You can move any of the slider buttons from Broad towards Exact and then click the pencil icon to do a new search. You can also click the "Hide fields" link, or change the record search focus to a certain collection (and then click Apply).
  5. The "Filters" section (left side) enables you to see the results for any of the collection types listed. Click a records category in the list to display results on the right side.

name: Search Ancestry Record Collections
summary: This Goal helps you find record and data collections on Ancestry, as well as explore the Card Catalog.

choices.name: Find record collections to investigate.

content.text:
1. Click Search (top menu) and select All Collections.
    Note : You can also select record collections from the Search menu.
  2. In the Jump back in box (right side), click an entry (if available) or click View All.
  3. In the Explore by collections box (right side), click an entry. A Search page for the collection appears, with items such as the following:
    • Collection information
    • Sample images
    • Search tips
    • Narrow by category (bold entry) or Browse catalog (non-bold entry)
    • Featured data collections

resources.description: Watch this video to learn more about searching record collections on Ancestry.

choices.name: Explore the Card Catalog.

hidden.content:
• * Good: Do Card Catalog searches for two or more ancestors in your tree, using at least three of the options explained in this Choice.
  • * Proficient: Do basic searches for five or more ancestors in your tree, using at least five of the options explained in this Choice.

content.text:
The Card Catalog is a searchable listing of all Ancestry collections.

  1. In the Search menu click Card Catalog, or in a Search screen click View all in card catalog (lower right).




  2. To search for an entry in the Card Catalog, fill in the Title and a Keyword and click Search.
  3. To reduce (filter) the list of collections, click one of the following:
    • Filter by category (first list)
    • Filter by Location
    • Filter by Dates
  4. To sort the list of collections, click Sort By (upper right) and select a sort method from the list.
  5. To display a different page of collection results, click a page number at the bottom of the screen, or click a left or right arrow.

resources.description: Learn more about the Ancestry Card Catalog in this article and video.

choices.name: Search for a data collection.

hidden.content:
• Open a data collection of interest.
  • Select the record types you want.
  • Set the terms for your search.

• * Good: Do Data Collection searches for two or more ancestors in your tree, using at least five of the options explained in this Choice.
  • * Proficient: Do basic searches for five or more ancestors in your tree, using at least eight of the options explained in this Choice.

content.text:
Note : There are many data collections to search in Ancestry, from Special Collections to the Card Catalog. The steps below demonstrate how to search for birth, marriage, and death data collections.

  1. In the Search menu (top of the screen), choose Birth, Marriage, & Death.



  2. To select a different set of records to search, use "Narrow by Category" or "Featured Data Collections" (right side).
  3. Fill in the following Search fields as needed:
    • Name (First/Middle and Last)
    • Birth year and location
    • Death year and location
    • Any event (year)
    • Father's Name (First/Middle and Last)
    • Mother's Name (First/Middle and Last)
    • Spouse's Name (First/Middle and Last)—you can also click the Spouse link to add another spouse to search for
    • Child's Name (First/Middle and Last)—you can also click the Child link to add another spouse to search for
  4. To require that the Search fields be exactly matched in the search, check the "Match All Terms Exactly" box (at the top).
  5. To specify a keyword to search for, type it in the Keyword box. To require an exact match for what's in the keyword field, enclose it in quotes.
  6. Select a gender if desired.
  7. To limit the search to a certain collection, click Collection Focus and select the collection from the list.
  8. Click Search to perform the record search. A results window opens with links to records that may match the person you searched for.

name: Analyze Search Results
summary: This Goal helps you get the most from your Ancestry search results, including refining searches for optimal results.

choices.name: Review recent searches.

hidden.content:
• * Good: Review the data in two different searches you have done, including at least three options listed in this Choice. Make note of information you want to add for people in your tree.
  • * Proficient: Same as Good, for at least three different searches and all the options.

content.text:
1. In the Your recent searches box (in the Search screen, below the main Search fields), click a link with the name of a person you recently searched for. The Search Results screen for the person is displayed; see Choice B below for tips on working with search results.
  2. To see details for all recent searches, in the Your recent searches box click View All. You can then click an ancestor name to review the search attributes, view basic ancestor details, see the date of the search, and delete a search by clicking its trash icon.
  3. To switch to recently viewed records, click Viewed Content (upper left) and click a records link in the list.
  4. To switch to recently viewed data collections, click Viewed Collections (upper left) and click a data collection in the list.

resources.description: For tips on viewing or downloading records in Ancestry, read this article.

links.text: AC—Viewing, Downloading, or Printing a Record Image

resources.description: For additional tips on doing searches, read this article.

choices.name: Redo a search if necessary.

hidden.content:
• * Good: Redo at least two searches you did previously, using three or more of the options in this Choice. Make note of any new information you find in the revised searches.
  • * Proficient: Same as Good, for at least three different searches and all the options.

content.text:
After you perform a search or view a recent search (see Goal 5), the search results are displayed. This includes a graphic summary at the top that shows family information for the person searched for. If you need to modify a search and try again, follow the steps below.

  1. To change Search filters to be more broad, or more exact, click and drag any of the filters on their tracks. When you hover over a filter, a description appears, explaining each level of exactness.
  2. To restrict the search to a certain collection, click All Collections and select a location.
  3. If you need to edit the search terms,
    a) Click the pencil icon (Edit Search);
    b) Change any search fields as needed (see Goal 4, Choice B);
    c) Use the "Exact" checkboxes as needed (see Choice C below); and
    d) Click Search.
  4. To complete the revision of the search terms, click Apply.



  5. To display a different page of search results, click a page number at the bottom of the screen, or click a green left or right arrow.
  6. To use keyboard shortcuts for searches and image viewing, click "Shortcut Keys" (bottom left) and press one of the indicated keys when needed.
  7. To begin a new search, click the three-dot icon and select New Search.

choices.name: Work with "exact" search parameters.

hidden.content:
• Use an exact match when searching.
  • Konw how exact matches affect search fields.

• * Good: Do variations of "exact" searches for at least two ancestors, using several of the options in this Choice. Make note of any new information you find in the revised searches.
  • * Proficient: Same as Good, for at least three different searches and eight options.

content.text:
When you begin typing in a search field, you can specify a variety of "exact" search parameters for it.

  1. To require a match for all search terms you enter, in the Edit Search screen, click "Match all terms exactly".
  2. In the results screen, to control exactness for names and for birth, marriage, and death information in the search, slide an entry from broad towards exact.
  3. Controlling the exactness for the last name in the search is similar to the previous step, but instead of the Initial option there is a Soundex option (alternate spellings for the surname).
  4. To control exactness for names in the search, select an option. These include combinations of Exact, Similar, Sounds like, and Initials.
  5. For birth or other event years in the search, select Within 10 years, Within five years, Within two years, Within one year, or Exact to the year.
  6. For all place fields and remaining name fields, select an option. These include Country, Adjacent States, States, Adjacent Counties, Counties, and This Place.

choices.name: Examine all record search results for a person.

hidden.content:
• Find results for records you search.
  • View records of interest in the results.
  • Save a record image to a variety of places.

• * Good: Examine records for at least two ancestors, using three or more of the options in this Choice. Save the search results to your computer or device.
  • * Proficient: Same as Good, for at least three ancestors and five options.

content.text:
1. In the center of the results screen, hover over a records link to see a preview (if available).


  2. Click a records link to display the Detail tab. (Source information is available in the Source tab.)








  3. To see a record image, if available, click it (left side). The link may take you to an external site, or it may display a record in an Ancestry viewer. In the latter case, follow the viewing guidelines below.
  4. In the image window, click and drag the image to move it.
  5. Click the zoom slider to change magnification, or click the Enlarge icon to view full-screen.
  6. To hide or show the index panel, click the right-arrow icon.
  7. To make adjustments to the image, such as rotate, flip, etc., click the Tool icon. See Project 2: Family Tree, Goal 5, Choice D for details on adjusting images.
  8. To save the record image in this screen, click Save (upper right) and select one of these:
    • Save to person in your tree (navigate to person)
    • Save to computer ...
    • Save to Shoebox

choices.name: Use additional options for record search results.

content.text:
1. To add a comment for the results page, type it in the "Write a comment" field (lower right) and click Submit .
  2. To find others who are researching your search person,
    a) In the Make a Connection box (lower right), click the "Find others" link;
    b) Browse the information on the right side of the screen; and
    c) Click a Member Tree link to see Profile information for the search person, in the member's Ancestry tree.
  3. To submit alternate information to Ancestry for the person in the record,
    a) Click "Add or update information" (lower left, if available);
    b) Click the "Choose" field and select the type of alternate information;
    c) Click the "Reason" field and select a reason for the change;
    d) Update the information;
    e) (Optional) Click "Explain or source your update" and type your source information in the box; and
    f) Click Submit.
  4. To print the page, click the Print icon (upper right) and complete the Print dialog.
  5. To share the page, click the Share icon (upper right) and choose one of the social media platforms.

choices.name: Examine search results for categories.

content.text:
1. In the "All results for (name)" screen, click an entry in the Filters section (left side).
  2. Examine the record category links and click any that are of interest. Remember that these categories may include records for other people with the same name as the person you searched for.
  3. In the list of results, click "View Record" for one you are interested in. See Choice D above for details.
  4. To see summary information for a record collection, click its link in the list. You can then click "View Record" (same as View details in Choice D above).
  5. To see additional results, if any, click "See all (number) results" at the bottom of the list.

name: Use Homepage Options
section_name: Use Homepage options to aid your research.
summary: The Homepage for your Ancestry tree has several useful options to aid in your research and record organization.

choices.name: Use Search and My Quick Links.

content.text:
1. For convenience, you can use the Search box (upper right) on the homepage. For details on using searches, see Goal 4.
  2. Use the My Quick Links widget to access your own favorite set of record collections. For details on My Quick Links, see Choice C in Goal 3 of Project 1: Welcome.

choices.name: Explore new record collections.

content.text:
1. In the "What's Happening at Ancestry" box, click any of the links for new record collections.
  2. To see all new and updated collections, click See All New Records. You can select a country in the drop-down list, and collections that are coming soon are listed on the right side. To see additional collections, click "Show more" at the bottom of the collections list.

choices.name: Explore items on the home page.

hidden.content: • * Proficient: Use the to-do list to build up a list of five or more research tasks.

content.text:
1. In the top menu, click Home.
  2. Ancestry supplies a number of informational items that may be of interest, such as
    • Recently modified—ancestors whose information was recently changed.
    • Your daily picks—documents and other items from ancestors.
    • Hints—from suggested record collections.
    • In remembrance—anniversaries of death dates.
    • Potential ancestors
    • Upcoming anniversaries—for ancestor marriages.
    • School lists and yearbooks
    • Review stories
    • Upcoming birthdays

choices.name: Manage records in your Ancestry Shoebox.

hidden.content:
• * Good: Save at least two useful ancestor records to your Shoebox.
  • * Proficient: Save at least two useful ancestor records to your Shoebox.

content.text:
The Shoebox is a place where you can store a copy of a record as you decide if and how to use it in your tree.



  1. To add a record to your Shoebox,
    a) Do a search to find the record (see the previous Goals in the Project);
    b) View the record; and
    c) Click Save and select "Save to your Shoebox".
  2. To view the shoebox, click the Shoebox link on the home page, in the Tools and Resources section (right side). Or, from the records screen, click the "shoebox" link (just above Detail). The Saved Records tab shows a link to each record in the shoebox and information about it.
  3. To see records you have downloaded and printed (see Goal 6, Choice D), click the Downloaded and Printed Records tab.
  4. To scroll to other pages while in either of the tabs, click the arrows at the bottom of the screen or enter a page number in the box.
  5. If you want to remove the record from your Shoebox, click the trash icon in the Shoebox screen, or click "Remove" in the Search results page (above Detail).

resources.description: For more information on using the Ancestry shoebox, read this article.

name: Develop Search Skills
section_name: Develop your skills in searching records. Vault
summary: The better your search skills, the more time you are likely to spend looking in the right places, and the better the results.

choices.name: Improve your search techniques.

hidden.content:
• Start searches broadly and then narrow them down.
  • Search for unique family member names first.
  • Small clues can help determine the differences when a person has a common name.

• What topics are helpful for genealogical research?
  • WorldCat.org
  • Internet Archive
  • OpenLibrary.org
  • Reclaim the Records
  • Digital Public Library of America
  • Hathi Trust
  • Google Books

• * Good: Write down key learnings from this Choice, and then apply them in your own record searches for an ancestor.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, for two ancestors.

content.text:
1. Apply best practices in the Internet searches you do, such as searching broadly at first and then more narrowly, and searching for unusual names before common names.

    ☆ FS—Internet Search Tips
    ☆ BYU—Using the Internet Like a Pro—60:44 - 2020  
    • What topics are helpful for genealogical research?
    • WorldCat.org
    • Internet Archive
    • OpenLibrary.org
    • Reclaim the Records
    • Digital Public Library of America
    • Hathi Trust
    • Google Books



  2. Get tips on doing record searches in FamilySearch.

    ☆ RIV—Searching with FamilySearch - 2018

  3. Here are four tips for searching genealogy databases.

    ☆ 4 Things to Do when Using a Genealogy Database - 2017

choices.name: Use Google (www.google.com) to conduct effective searches for ancestor names, dates, places, etc.

hidden.content:
• Google can be successfully used for genealogy if you pay attention to how you're searching. Key words, spelling variations, and the way a search is phrased can all affect the quality of the results.
  • Take advantage of the Advanced Search and Location options Google offers to help you narrow down results.

• * Good: Use Google searched with variations for 5 ancestors.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, and use advanced Google searches, for at least 8 ancestors. Also

content.text:
1. To use Google to find a person in the ancestors.familysearch.org site,
    a) Type the first and last name, along with birth or death date, or both, and FamilySearch, and press Enter. For example:
    Ross Willard Colberg (1917-1979) FamilySearch
    b) Click the result on the Google page. You can see a summary of information about the person and then sign in to FamilySearch to see more.
  2. Basics: Learn how to use basic search variations in Google.

    ☆ FMP—Google Your Family Tree - 2021
    ☆ RIV—Genealogy Toolbox (p. 3-12) - 2018

  3. Learn how to use and refine Google searches.

    ☆ RT—The Genealogist’s Google Search Methodology - 2019
    ☆ GI—How to Refine Google Searches

  4. Advanced: Use the options available in the Google Advanced Search screen.
  5. Learn how to use advanced operators with Google searches.

    ☆ Advanced Operators Reference, Google Guide

  6. AncestorSearch: Learn about a shorcut tool for Google Ancestor Searches, from the Randy Majors site.

    ☆ Have you tried AncestorSearch on Google Search? - 2019

  7. Images: Learn how to do reverse image searches with Google to identify photos and pictures.

    ☆ Google Reverse Image Search—3:00

  8. Tools: Learn how to use a variety of Google tools in your research.

    ☆ FS—Google Tools for Genealogy—18:35 - 2021

choices.name: Use name techniques in searches to produce better results.

hidden.content:
• Spelling variations are an important concept to understand with genealogical research.
  • People were often recorded by their nickname, so learn potential variants of a name. Some may be more obvious than others.
  • Wildcards (*) are used in searches to help bring up results that include spelling variants.

• * Good: Use name variations and wildcard searches with 3 ancestors.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, for at least 8 ancestors.

content.text:
1. Account for spelling and name variations as you search records. Read these articles for tips.

    ☆ FMP—Name Variations: Tips and Tricks - 2016
    ☆ AC—Searching with Spelling Variations

  2. Read this article for additional tips on using name variations.

    ☆ TH—Tips for Finding Alternate Spellings - 2019

  3. Nicknames: Learn to recognize possible nicknames for ancestors.

    ☆ TH—Matching Nicknames with Given Names
    ☆ FT—Female Ancestor First Names and Nicknames

  4. Here are some tips for handling full names, nicknames, and initials in searches.

    ☆ What’s in a Name: Full Names, Nicknames & Initials

  5. Wildcards: Use wildcards effectively in FamilySearch searches.

    ☆ Searching with Wildcards in FamilySearch - 2016

  6. Use wildcards effectively in Ancestry searches.

    ☆ AC—Wildcards and Search Options—30:00 - 2014



  7. Names and surnames: Use these tips when searching for ancestors with common (often occurring) surnames.

    ☆ LDS—Finding Ancestors with Common Names
    ☆ 3 Tips for Researching an Ancestor With a Common Name - 2016

name: Solve Research Problems
section_name: Solve problems and use effective research methods. Vault
summary: When research challenges arise, they don't need to derail your progress. With some best practices and creative thinking, you can keep your family history work moving along.

choices.name: Learn to avoid common mistakes in research.

hidden.content:
• Getting hung up on spelling
  • Avoiding the spelling issue
  • Adding records too quickly
  • Avoiding adding the wrong record
  • Jumping back too quickly
  • Avoiding jumping too quickly
  • Focusing only on direct ancestors
  • Avoiding blinders
• * Proficient: Study the resources in this Choice, and then write down key learnings you can use in your research.

content.text:
Examples of common mistakes include:

  1. Beginning: Learn about research pitfalls for beginning genealogists.

    ☆ LT—Research Pitfalls of Beginning Genealogists
    ☆ AR—Beginner Mistakes and How to Avoid Them—18:26 - 2013  
    • Getting hung up on spelling
    • Avoiding the spelling issue
    • Adding records too quickly
    • Avoiding adding the wrong record
    • Jumping back too quickly
    • Avoiding jumping too quickly
    • Focusing only on direct ancestors
    • Avoiding blinders



  2. Common Mistakes: Learn how to avoid three mistakes that genealogists often make.

    ☆ AJC—3 Biggest Mistakes in Genealogy Research - 2020

  3. Watch these videos for more information about common mistakes in family history research.

    ☆ AC—Common Mistakes in Genealogy, Part 1—22:46 - 2012


    ☆ AC—Common Mistakes in Genealogy, Part 2—26:54 - 2013



  4. Learn how to overcome bad habits in your research.

    ☆ FL—Genealogy Research in the 21st Century Part 2: Overcoming Bad Research Habits - 2020

  5. Assumptions: Avoid preconceived notions in research, such as: "The genealogy information given to me must be correct;" "Records are always complete and accurate;" "All events have exact dates and places available."
  6. Learn about mistaken assumptions in genealogy research.

    ☆ AC—Preconceived Notions—29:05 (start 3:00) - 2014


    ☆ RT—Perilous Assumptions - 2019

  7. Other: Understand how mistaken identities occur and how to avoid them.

    ☆ GC—Mistaken Identity

choices.name: Understand potential problems with terms and records.

hidden.content:
• Understand genealogy terms thoroughly.
  • Know the basic types of record problems and discrepancies.

• * Good: Write down key learnings for understanding record problems.
  • * Proficient: Same as above; also include estimating, and critical analysis.

content.text:
1. Understanding Terms: Be familiar with terms that may have confusing uses in genealogy:
    • Word meanings
    • Latin terms
    • Old medical terms
    • Name and word spellings
  2. Record Problems: Read the articles to discover possible record problems and how to address them.

    ☆ GC—Potential Problems with Records
    ☆ LDS—Dealing with Errors

  3. Get an introduction to record contradictions and discrepancies.

    ☆ FS—Contradictions and discrepancies
    ☆ AAC—Accuracy and Error in Records, Narratives, and Other Sources—9:49 (acct. req.)

  4. Learn how to overcome problems caused by misindexed records.

    ☆ AF—MisIndexing — A Common Brick Wall and How to Get Around It - 2019

  5. Watch this video to learn about how to deal with unreliable evidence.

    ☆ AAC—Working With Unreliable Evidence—4:46 (acct. req.)

  6. Learn about "revolving door" ancestors, or those who have been added to shared online trees without proper sources.

    ☆ JT—What are revolving door ancestors and why do they exist? - 2021

  7. Here are some additional tips for working with information in records.

    ☆ AAC—Look at Both Sides of Documents—3:05 (acct. req.)

choices.name: Use evidence to resolve conflicting information.

hidden.content:
• Spelling variations and misspellings can be caused by a pronunciation differences, handwriting, or simple recording errors.
  • A name might be written one way in the actual document and indexed differently. Some records may be more difficult to find and require additional strategy to locate.
  • People were often recorded by their nickname, so learn potential variants of a name. Some may be more obvious than others.
  • Use discrepancy charts.
  • Resolve conflicting evidence.

• Direct evidence
  • Indirect evidence
  • Negative evidence
  • Summary

• What is the "same name trap"?
  • Case Study 1
  • Case Study 2
  • Case Study 3
  • TipsFile your notes

• Start with what you know
  • Move from the known to the unknown
  • Collect and analyze all sources

• * Proficient: Find an ancestor whose notes or Person page information indicate conflicting evidence or a problem with parentage. Then use the key points in the articles and video above to develop a plan to resolve the differences.

content.text:
1. Parentage: Document parentage accurately, as explained in this Ancestry video.

    ☆ AC—Documenting Parentage—31:30 - 2016  
    • Direct evidence
    • Indirect evidence
    • Negative evidence
    • Summary




  2. Learn to avoid following the wrong lines in your research.

    ☆ PR—Barking Up the Wrong (Family) Tree

  3. Learn how to deal with finding multiple people with the same name as your ancestor.

    ☆ GC—Other Danger Zones: Mistaken Identity
    ☆ BYU—Double Trouble: Avoiding the Same Name Trap—32:16 - 2019  
    • What is the "same name trap"?
    • Case Study 1
    • Case Study 2
    • Case Study 3
    • TipsFile your notes




  4. This article explains how to develop a research plan for men with the same name.

    ☆ FL—Revisiting a Research Project—Men of the Same Name - 2020

  5. Learn how to work with ancestors who may have changed their names.

    ☆ AJC—When Ancestors Changed Names - 2022

Analyzing Evidence
  1. Analysis: Use discrepancy charts to track the differences in varying versions of an ancestor's line.

    ☆ GC—Organize the Inconclusive

  2. Learn how to do critical analysis of your research findings.

    ☆ FS—Evaluate the Evidence

  3. Here are some tips for evaluating evidence in the records you are working with.

    ☆ LT: Evidence Analysis Explained Part II: Evaluating Genealogy Information
    ☆ LT: Evidence Analysis Explained Part III: Evaluating Genealogical Evidence

  4. Resolving Conflicts: Learn more about how to resolve conflicting evidence.

    ☆ AC—Resolving Conflicting Evidence—38:13 - 2014  
    • Start with what you know
    • Move from the known to the unknown
    • Collect and analyze all sources



    ☆ LDS—Dealing with Contradictory Evidence

  5. Use these approaches to handle conflicting evidence in research.

    ☆ AR—How To Handle Conflicting Evidence: A Six-Step Program - 2013
    ☆ RT—When Details Disagree: 8 Ways to Resolve Conflicts - 2019

  6. Learn about correlating genealogy evidences.

    ☆ GTV—Correlation of Evidence—6:57 - 2019



  7. Explore the Evidence Analysis Process Map by Elizabeth Shown Mills.
  8. Watch this video for tips on recognizing when your research information is correct.

    ☆ AAC—How Do I Know When I Am Right?—55:39 (acct. req.)

  9. Learn how to write solid conclusions for your genealogical research.

    ☆ RT—Where's the Proof? Organizing and Writing Genealogical Findings

choices.name: Use effective tools and techniques.

hidden.content:
• Summarizing and abstracting can help pinpoint the main content of a document and make it easier to reference later.
  • Documents should be used together to correlate data and come to a conclusion, even if that conclusion is that the findings are inconclusive.
  • People often lived and moved in groups, so strategies like cluster genealogy can be used to help find more potential ancestors.
  • Using multiple kinds of records is crucial in discovering information that is not explicitly stated in a document.

• Geographic clusters
  • BillionGraves Plus
  • Findmypast
  • Think in terms of clusters

• The value of case studies
  • Red flags on Elizabeth's page
  • Principles of problem solving
  • Check sources
  • Check the Change Log
  • Summary of clues
  • Next steps
  • Fixing incorrect merge

• * Good: Write down key learnings for summarizing records, correlating records, and using discrepancy charts. Then apply these principles to research for one or more ancestors.
  • * Proficient: Same as above; also include cluster genealogy and inferential genealogy.

content.text:
1. Abstracts: Learn about using abstracts in genealogy research.

    ☆ AF—What Is an Abstract? - 2016

  2. Correlation: Use Correlation approaches to piece together records. With correlation, you can draw conclusions that are supported by the evidence, even though specific facts may be missing.

    ☆ FS—Using a Correlation Approach—45:40 - 2012

  3. Cluster/FAN: Use "cluster genealogy" to research the family members of direct ancestors. This approach, often referred to as "FAN" (Friends and Neighbors) can often lead to additional clues.

    ☆ FTM—Ways to Solve Genealogy Problems with Cluster Research
    ☆ BYU—Locating Your Ancestors Using Clusters—55:29 - 2016
      
    • Geographic clusters
    • BillionGraves Plus
    • Findmypast
    • Think in terms of clusters




  4. Learn how to examine your ancestor's neighborhood for research and historical clues.

    ☆ AR—Resources for Examining Your Ancestor's Neighborhood - 2014

  5. Inferential: Use Inferential Genealogy techniques to work with goals, searches, records and evidences. Start with a focused goal; search broadly; understand the records; correlate the evidence; and write down the results.

    ☆ FS Wiki—Inferential Genealogy

  6. Case Studies: Explore practical case studies in genealogy research.

    ☆ TH—Genealogy Case Studies - 2019

  7. Watch this example and learn about the value of case studies.

    ☆ BYU—Case Study: Double Trouble with Elizabeth Hepton—49:03 - 2020  
    • The value of case studies
    • Red flags on Elizabeth's page
    • Principles of problem solving
    • Check sources
    • Check the Change Log
    • Summary of clues
    • Next steps
    • Fixing incorrect merge




  8. Watch these videos to see case studies of real-time research on genealogy challenges.

    ☆ BYU—Case Studies Live On Air (1)—51:51 - 2022
    ☆ BYU—Case Studies Live On Air (2)—54:21 - 2022

  9. Calendars/Dates: Use calendars and dates effectively.

    ☆ Calendars and Dates

choices.name: Use creative approaches to solve problems in non-typical ways.

hidden.content:
• Expanding your research target and searching for children or other relatives can help overcome some of the challenges that arise.
  • Stay organized and document all research so you know what has already been done and what needs to be done.
  • Try approaching the problem from different perspectives.

• * Good: Select at least three strategies discussed in this Choice and apply them to research for an ancestor.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, with at least 5 strategies and two ancestors.

content.text:
Creative approaches to research can help you make progress when traditional methods aren't working well.

  1. Tips and Tactics: Read this article to learn about proven tips and tactics that reach "out of the box" for results.

    ☆ FS—Tips and Tactics—8 pgs. - 2010

  2. Learn about "detective techniques" for family history in this video.

    ☆ PBS—History Detectives

  3. Learn to use creative approaches in your research.

    ☆ FS—Thinking Creatively About Research Problems—39:17 - 2010

  4. Learn how to use middle names in your ancestor research.

    ☆ AF—Tips for Doing Middle Name Research - 2022

  5. Children and Others: Learn how to find missing ancestors by searching for their children.

    ☆ LDS—Find Missing Ancestors by Searching for Children

  6. Learn how to find missing ancestors by researching other people.

    ☆ AJC—How to Find Your Ancestor by Researching Other People - 2016

  7. Mind Maps: Use "mind maps" as explained in this article.

    ☆ Mind Mapping for Genealogists - 2012
    ☆ FL: Look at Your Family in a Whole New Way with a Mind Map - 2016

  8. Swim Lanes: Learn how to use "swim lanes" to track your research when dealing with complex issues.

    ☆ RT—Swim Lanes: A New Analysis Tool for Tricky Situations in Family History Research—4:27 - 2022

choices.name: Use photographs to aid in your genealogical research.

hidden.content:
• Daguerrotype
  • Ambrotype

  • Using photographers to date photos
  • Building a reference guide

• Exposure
  • Focus
  • Camera Movement

  • Is equipment important?

  • Camera vs. scanners
  • Post-production editing

• A quick look at some of the problems
  • Underexposed
  • Out of focus
  • What photos can't I fix?
  • What programs should I use?

  • Steep learning curve
  • Steps

  • What are the ethics of editing?

content.text:
1. Finding/Using Photos: Use existing photos to further your research work. Look for photos that arouse your curiosity or that seem to have a story to tell.

    ☆ FS—Use Photos to Enhance Your Research - 2015
    ☆ GC—Using Photos in Your Research

  2. Learn how to find family photos online.

    ☆ LT—How to Find Family Photos Online

  3. Watch this video to learn how to find historical photos online.

    ☆ AAC—Finding Ancestral Photos Online—24:00 (acct. req.)

  4. Here are 30 tips from Findmypast on using family photos for genealogy.

    ☆ FMP—30 Tips for Using Family Photos for Genealogy - 2020

  5. Dates: Learn how to date photographs in their approximate times, in the article below and on the PhotoTree site (use the Identification and articles tabs).

    ☆ GC—Dating Your Photographs
    ☆ Identifying Old Photos by Time Period or Date—46:36 - 2022  
    • Daguerrotype
    • Ambrotype
    • Ferrotypes
    • Carte de Visite
    • Cabinet cards
    • Other mounted photographs
    • Using photographers to date photos
    • Building a reference guide




  6. Clues: Find historical fashion clues for your photographs, in the article below and on the Fashion History Timeline site (use the Time Period tab to select a century and decade).

    ☆ AC—Dating Family Photographs Using Historical Fashion Clues - 2015

  7. Find clues in photo captions and labels.

    ☆ AC—Bad Photos, Good Genealogy - 2015

  8. Find hidden secrets in old photos.

    ☆ AR—Magical Hidden Secrets In Your Old Photos - 2012

  9. Learn about reviewing and studying photographs in this video.

    ☆ AAC—Reviewing and Studying Photographs—2:45 (acct. req.)

Taking/Editing Photographs
  1. Here are some tips for taking better family history photos.

    ☆ BYU—How to Take Better Photos for Genealogy—66:31 - 2020

choices.name: Know what alternatives you can try when research is slowed or stopped.

hidden.content: • Consulting others or a professional, finding original copies of records, reviewing current research, and researching siblings are just a few ways to help overcome brick walls in research.

• * Good: Select at least three strategies discussed in this Choice and apply them to an ancestor who has been a research challenge.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, with at least 5 strategies and two ancestors.

content.text:
1. Questions: Know what questions to ask before declaring a "brick wall".

    ☆ LDS—Questions to Ask Yourself Before Declaring a Brick Wall

  2. Solutions: Here's a great list of breakthrough items for research, from Findmypast.com.

    ☆ FMP—13 Tips to Try when Your Family Tree Leaves You Stumped

  3. Here is some helpful advice on cracking your genealogy brick walls.

    ☆ AC—Breaking through Your Genealogy Brick Wall—32:06 - 2013
    ☆ AC—The Dreaded Brick Wall - 2014

  4. Learn tips in these articles for handling challenging situations.

    ☆ GC—Impossible and Improbable
    ☆ FS—Solving Tough Research Problems

  5. Read this blog article by Amy Johnson Crow to see how she brainstorms through a research wall.

    ☆ AJC—Brainstorming Through a Brick Wall - 2017

  6. Watch the video to learn how foundational thinking can help solve brick wall problems.

    ☆ AAC—When You Find a Brick Wall, Develop Foundational Thinking—35:03 (acct. req.)

  7. Reaching Out: This case study highlights the value of reaching out to break through walls.

    ☆ LT—Solving Genealogy Brick Walls By Reaching Out

  8. Negative Results: Learn how "negative results" can be helpful in your research.

    ☆ LT—The Upside of Negative Results

name: Take a Family History Trip
section_name: Take a family history trip. Vault
summary: There's nothing like being there ... You can deepen your family history experience by planning and taking trips, short or long, to places connected with your ancestors.

choices.name: Plan your family history trip.

hidden.content:
• Family History trips can provide a unique insight regarding your ancestors.
  • Before taking your trip, know what the area has to offer and what you will need in order to access archives or libraries, to see original records.
• * Proficient: Decide on a place for a family history trip, and then write down key learnings from the resources in this Choice.

content.text:
1. Make a list of locations of interest for research or gathering memories, and then decide where you will go.
  2. Watch this video for tips on planning family history trips.

    ☆ FS—Planning and Implementing a Research Trip—53:32 - 2015

  3. Use suggestions from these videos in planning for a successful trip.

    ☆ AC—Taking a Family History Vacation—20:08 - 2013



    ☆ FS—Take a Genealogy Trip with Tiff—24:36 - 2010

choices.name: Do effective research at the remote site.

hidden.content:
• Come prepared and have a list of what you expect to find and where, when going onsite.
  • After you’ve collecting information, make sure you organize and file it effectively. Backup all data and make to-do lists and done files.
  • Share your findings with others and use your knowledge to find new research projects.
• * Proficient: Maximize your research quality at the remote site, and use your research findings effectively.

content.text:
1. Learn the techniques of doing remote research.

    ☆ FS—Doing On-Site Research—29:55

  2. Here are some suggestions for places to do onsite research.

    ☆ PR—6 Places for Onsite Genealogical Researchs

  3. Learn what do do with your research findings.

    ☆ GC—What to Do after a Genealogy Trip

  4. For more information on accessing archive and library resources, see Goal F5 in the United States page, or corresponding goals in other Country pages.

name: Descendant Research
section_name: Learn how to do descendancy research. Vault
summary: Descendancy research can be an efficient way to find descendants of ancestors (such as distant cousins). For a detailed look at how cousin relationships work, see "Are Your Cousins Removed?" Remember that FamilySearch does not display information for living people, beyond your immediate family.

choices.name: Learn the basics of descendancy research.

hidden.content: • * Proficient: Write down 5 key learnings about descendancy research from the article and videos in this Choice.

content.text:
1. Learn about the "why's" of descendancy research in this article.

    ☆ FS—Finding the Past in the Present

  2. Learn about easy steps for descendancy research.

    ☆ FS—Easy Steps Handout

  3. Get an overview of descendant research.

    ☆ AAC—Descendant Research—3:34 (acct. req.)
    ☆ PR—Descendant Research

  4. Learn the basic approaches for descendancy research.

    ☆ BYU—Stategies for Finding an Ancestor Through Descendancy Research—18:14 - 2016


    Descendancy Research: Another Pathway to Genealogy—56:30 - 2016

name: Reading Difficult Handrwiting
section_name: Improve your ability to read difficult handwriting. Vault
summary: Hard-to-read handwriting is a fact of life for older records. Being able to better read it will help you make more progress with original research as well indexing records.

choices.name: Learn the basics of deciphering handwriting.

hidden.content:
• Handwriting is unique to each person, and different regions often used different types of script.
  • Compare difficult-to-read words to other letters and words in the document.
  • Consulting others for help is also an effective strategy when you're at an impasse.
• * Proficient: Write down key learnings from the articles.

content.text:
1. Get a quick reference for interpreting handwritten letters in various languages.

    ☆ FS—Handwriting Helps

  2. Here are examples of alphabet letters as sometimes written in earlier U.S. records.

    ☆ Old Handwriting

  3. Learn what to do when you have difficulty reading handwriting on a record.

    ☆ 5 Steps to Take When Your Ancestor's Name is Unreadable

  4. Study these articles to learn basic skills that help you with handwritten records.

    ☆ FS—United States Handwriting
    ☆ AR—Howell To Reed Difficult Handrighting - 2011

choices.name: Learn more techniques for difficult handwriting.

hidden.content:
• Reading aloud slowly can help you decipher a document.
  • Words were often written phonetically instead of the standardized way we know them now.
  • Become familiar with terminology used in old times.

• * Good: Write down key learnings from the articles. Then find an indexing batch from an older time period and practice your handwriting analysis.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, with three older indexing batches.

content.text:
1. Hers are some useful tips in deciphering difficult handwriting.

    ☆ RT—Yes! You Can Read That Handwriting! - 2019

  2. Read this article to increase your understanding of old handwriting.

    ☆ FMP—11 Tips for Reading Old Handwriting

  3. Use the online tutorials from the British National Archives, for handwriting from 1500-1800.
  4. Use the online tutorials for Latin from the British National Archives.
  5. Read this article to learn about reading Elizabethan Secretary handwriting.

    ☆ FS—How do I read Elizabethan secretary hand? - 2020

choices.name: (Optional) Get online help with deciphering old or difficult handwriting.

content.text:
1. Get free help with handwriting deciphering from members of the RootsChat forum.
  2. Explore paleography questions in the Genealogy Stack Exchange.

choices.name: Learn about scripts and paleography (the study of old handwriting).

content.text:
1. Go to the Script Tutorial site for Indexers at Brigham Young University.
  2. To learn more about paleography in general, scroll down and click the link on the left.
  3. To learn more about paleography for a specific language, scroll down and click a link on the right to choose English, German, Dutch, Italian, French, Spanish, or Portuguese.
  4. Watch this video for tips on using the BYU Script Tutorials.

    ☆ BYU—BYU Script Tutorials—36:16 - 2022
